text.p: These are the leading stories in the Namibian press on Monday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Commercial and communal farmers are experiencing severe cashflow problems as a result of last year's drought. Difficulties are being added by delays in implementing a drought relief scheme under which farmers are to be paid cash incentives to replenish their stocks.

- A code for issuing new drivers' licences will become the norm for the whole of the Southern African Development Community region after its introduction in South Africa next year. The scheme is intended to reduce the apparently large-scale fraud in licensing departments.

- Sweden has agreed to fund the Namibian Environment and Tourism Ministry's national resources accounting programme, by which green considerations are to be brought into Namibia's economic planning process.
- The National Society for Human Rights has come out against a proposal that President Sam Nujoma be allowed to stand for the a third term as president.
